description: The course will focus on integrative aspects of physiological function of vertebrates. Comparative, environmental and quantitative approaches will be used. Major topics include muscle, the cardiovascular system, respiration, renal function and the nervous system.
name: VERTEBRATE PHYSIOLOGY

values.comments:
This is an intermediate course in biology providing an overview of the physiology of vertebrates, especially concerning the human organ systems. The prerequisite for the class is BIOL102, BIOL121, or BIOL124. The course consists of a co-taught lecture and a TA-run recitation, and grading is based on four equal-weight, non-cumulative exams and some homework problems. One of two texts is recommended: Boron's Human Physiology or Guyton's Textbook of Medical Physiology, which students rated as “excellent resources.” 

Most students felt that this course was “interesting” and “beneficial,” if somewhat disorganized. However, some noted that much of the material had already been covered in first-year biology, and that as a result they learned relatively little. Overall, students found the course good for specific details about particular systems, though some would have preferred more discussion of animal physiology. Other students felt that the content was “too quantitative,” involving more math and physics than expected, while lacking in depth of anatomical concepts.

Students had mixed reactions to Professor Ren. Most agreed that he was funny, interesting, and extremely dedicated to his students, being very accessible “even at night.” However, students felt that Prof. Ren was “ineffective at communicating” during lecture and that it was clearer to read the book than go to his lectures. A few students also had some difficulty understanding Prof. Ren's accent. Yet most felt that he was humorous enough to “salvage student interest.”

Most students in this course were Biology majors and/or pre-meds, which students felt generated a highly competitive atmosphere. Lecture slides were not made available, making it difficult to get makeup notes. Students had wildly different views about the four non-cumulative exams, ranging from “insultingly easy” to “could have been more challenging” to “purposefully difficult to generate a curve.” The general consensus was that exams were “fair,” but the lack of a relational curve was not. Most felt that the workload required for the class was “not too high” save for studying.
